Post\u2010selection on successful heralds yields a mid\u2010gap Bell pair at the central outputs only in the topological configuration, directly probing the chain\u2019s photonic mid\u2010gap entanglement and demonstrating its robustness against weak\u2010bond failure.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Path Teleportation Emulation of the J\u2081\u2013J\u2082 Frustrated Heisenberg Dimer\n\nAbstract: We implement a Pyth e us-compatible linear-optical network that teleports a qubit from node A to node C via two competing Bell-swapping paths with tunable source amplitudes encoding the J\u2081 and J\u2082 couplings of a two-spin Heisenberg dimer. Our scheme employs three probabilistic photonic Bell-pair sources, enforced frequency-demultiplexing via removed connections, a 6\u00d76 beam-splitter\u2013phase-shifter network, and four number-resolving detectors with post-selection to realize a single non-separable three-qubit projection across spectral bins, revealing inter-frequency coherence unattainable by independent Bell measurements.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Variational Low-Depth Three-Port Port-Based Teleportation\n\nMini-abstract: We propose the first Pytheus-compatible variational protocol for low-depth port-based teleportation with three ports, directly implementing the target \u201cVariational Low-Depth Port-Based Teleportation with Three Ports.\u201d Our linear-optical network uses three probabilistic Bell-pair sources and a single-photon emitter at Alice, a fixed two-layer beam-splitter and phase-shifter ansatz at the central measurement node, and number-resolving detectors to herald and route an unknown photonic qubit to one of three Bobs, with beam-splitter ratios and phase settings optimized to maximize average teleportation fidelity.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nMulti-Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering\n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe present an all\u2010linear\u2010optical protocol, \u201cMulti\u2010Path Entanglement Percolation via Parity Filtering in Irreversible Scattering,\u201d that fuses two Bell pairs A\u2013B\u2080 and C\u2080\u2013D into a high-fidelity link between remote photons A and D. By steering both B\u2080 and C\u2080 through unknown multimode scattering channels U\u2081,U\u2082 with programmable wavefront shapers and performing a single ancilla\u2010mediated parity filter across the combined outputs, an even-parity detection event heralds successful entanglement percolation without ever fully inverting the scattering matrices.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Experimental Realization of a Nonlocal Parity Gate for Semi-Quantum Key Agreement\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a target PyTheus-compatible linear-optical network in which two classical users, Alice and Bob, each send Z-basis single photons to a fully quantum node, Charlie, who entangles them with his ancilla Bell pair and performs post-selected entanglement-swapping to nonlocally compute their parity x\u2295y as a shared key bit. The target is the real part of the three-state Bargmann invariant Re\u2009Tr(\u03c1_A\u2009\u03c1_B\u2009\u03c1_C), whose quantized response statistics directly realize a genuine three-point quantum metric beyond pairwise SWAP tests.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nZak Phase Tomography via Closed-Loop Teleportation on a Photonic SSH Ring  \n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose a purely measurement-based photonic quantum network protocol that targets the Zak phase of the one-dimensional Su\u2013Schrieffer\u2013Heeger (SSH) model by teleporting a qubit sequentially around a four-site periodic ring using four probabilistic Bell swaps. Conditioned on four ancilla heralding clicks, the qubit returns to its original spatial mode with a relative phase shift exactly equal to the target Zak phase of the SSH band, which is then read out by a simple two-mode interferometer.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Linear-Optical S\u2083 Schur Analyzer for Measuring the Entanglement Spectrum of an Unknown Photonic Subsystem\n\nAbstract: We introduce a passive linear-optical network that mixes three independent SPDC-generated copies of an unknown subsystem A (modes 0,2,4) with vacuum ancilla and projects onto the symmetric, mixed, and antisymmetric S\u2083 irreducible subspaces via three ancillary detectors. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is the proposed target experiment for Pytheus:\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to create a photonic network that enacts two concurrent entanglement-swapping channels between distant modes 0 and 1, and then interferes them so that the final two-photon state is a coherent superposition of:\n  \u2013 Path S (\u201cstrong-coupling analog\u201d): a standard one-ancilla Bell-swap using ancilla modes 2 and 3  \n  \u2013 Path U (\u201cultrastrong-coupling analog\u201d): a two-ancilla cascade swap using ancilla modes 4 and 5  \n\nBy mixing modes {2,3,4,5} on an optimized linear interferometer (beam-splitters + phase-shifters) and heralding on exactly one photon in each ancilla detector, we project modes 0&1 onto  \n  |\u03a8\u27e9\u2080\u2081 \u221d |Bell\u2080\u2081 via S\u27e9 + e^{i\u03c6}|Bell\u2080\u2081 via U\u27e9\n\nThis realizes an \u201cultrastrong coupling\u201d regime in the sense that both the first-order (single-exchange) and second-order (cascade-exchange) processes contribute non\u2010perturbatively and coherently to the entanglement of 0&1. One can tune the relative amplitude and phase \u03c6 by adjusting beam-splitter reflectivities (the effective \u201ccoupling strengths\u201d) in the ancilla interferometer.\n\nVisualization of the network (photons flow top\u2192bottom):\n\n  Emitters (two probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources):\n     [A]\u2015\u2015\u2500> mode 0           [B]\u2015\u2015\u2500> mode 1  \n           \u2514\u2500> mode 2           \u2514\u2500> mode 3\n\n     [C]\u2015\u2015\u2500> mode 4           [D]\u2015\u2015\u2500> mode 5  \n\n  Ancilla interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus):\n     modes 2,3,4,5 \u2500\u2500\u2500 linear optical network \u2500\u2500\u2500 detectors a\u2082,a\u2083,a\u2084,a\u2085\n\n  Heralding condition:\n     one click in each detector a\u2082\u2013a\u2085 (total four clicks)\n\n  Outputs:\n     modes 0,1 are left in the target superposition state.\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2022 You can extend to Nth-order \u201cultrastrong\u201d paths by adding more ancilla pairs.  \n  \u2022 One can map out the nonperturbative scaling of entanglement fidelity vs. effective beam-splitter reflectivity, drawing a precise analogy to ultrastrong coupling phenomena.  \n  \u2022 Variants include teleportation rather than swapping, or three-node routers.\n\nThis target is purely a quantum\u2010network transformation (no static state generation), exploits only probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, and photon detection (all within Pytheus\u2019s scope), and defines a clear family of experiments bridging the \u201cstrong\u201d and \u201cultrastrong\u201d coupling analogues in entanglement distribution.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While the coherent superposition of a one-step vs. two-step entanglement\u2010swap channel is an appealing \u201cultrastrong-coupling analog,\u201d the core trick\u2014erasing which-swap information by mixing ancilla modes to project the 0\u20131 pair into a superposition of two swap processes\u2014is a straightforward extension of prior superposed-swap and partial-SWAP schemes. In particular, it closely parallels the heralded linear-optical partial-SWAP ultrastrong-coupling proposal and the superposed perfect-matching entanglement swaps already in the ensemble. Conditioning on exactly one click in each detector projects modes 0&1 onto the superposition\n  |\u03a8\u27e9\u2080\u2081 \u221d |Bell\u2080\u2081 via S\u27e9  + e^{i\u03c6} |Bell\u2080\u2081 via U\u27e9  \nwhere \u03c6 and the relative amplitude are tunable by the reflectivities and phases in the ancilla interferometer.\n\nVisualization (photons top\u2192bottom):\n\n  Pair sources:  \n    [A]\u2192(0,2)   [B]\u2192(1,3)  \n    [C]\u2192(2,4)   [D]\u2192(3,5)\n\n  Ancilla interferometer (to be optimized by Pytheus):\n    modes 2,3,4,5 \u2500\u2500 linear optics \u2500\u2500 detectors a\u2082, a\u2083, a\u2084, a\u2085\n\n  Outputs:\n    modes 0,1 heralded into the target superposition.\n\nGeneralizations:\n  \u2013 Add more ancilla pairs to realize Nth-order \u201cultrastrong\u201d swap contributions.  \n  \u2013 Map out entanglement fidelity vs. effective beam-splitter angles to emulate coupling-strength scaling.  \n  \u2013 Replace swapping by teleportation or extend to multi-node routers.\n\nThis is purely a network transformation (no static state generation), uses only probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, and threshold detectors\u2014all within Pytheus\u2019s capabilities.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposal boils down to coherently erasing \u201cwhich\u2010swap\u201d information to superpose a one\u2010step versus two\u2010step entanglement swap, which is essentially a direct combination of existing partial\u2010SWAP ultrastrong\u2010coupling analogues and superposed\u2010swap/perfect\u2010matching swap circuits already in the ensemble. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe standard entanglement swapping experiment uses probabilistic photon pair sources whereas this uses single photon sources.\\n\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two qutrits with single photon sources', 'foldername': 'ES3d_sp', 'bulk_thr': 0.0, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-09, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 10, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['00', '11', '22'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [0, 4], [1, 5], [1, 6], [1, 7]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"strong atom cavity coupling\" and \"ultrastrong coupling\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. First perform two independent Bell-swaps (A\u2013B and B\u2013C) in series (\u201cstrong coupling chain\u201d), then in parallel perform a three-mode joint measurement on three ancillas (\u201cultrastrong hub\u201d), and finally interfere the two ways to entangle A and C in one step.  \n\nStep 2:  \n  1. All four ancilla modes {2,3,4,5} enter an optimized linear-optical interferometer (beam-splitters & phase-shifters).  \n3. No prior protocol has explored this nonperturbative, causally indefinite entanglement distribution.  \nStep 5: It is feasible in Pytheus: it only needs six probabilistic pair-sources, a Mach-Zehnder style control interferometer, a four-mode ancilla interferometer, and heralded photon counts\u2014exactly within Pytheus\u2019s abstract linear-optics + detectors model.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus target for exploring a photonic quantum-SWITCH of entanglement-swapping orders, mapping \u201cstrong\u201d vs. \u201cultrastrong\u201d coupling to an indefinite-order network:\n\nEXPLANATION:\nWe want to entangle modes 0 & 1 by coherently superposing two swap sequences in an indefinite causal order controlled by a photonic Mach\u2013Zehnder:\n\n  \u2022 Path S (\u201cstrong-coupling analogue\u201d): a single-ancilla Bell swap between modes 2 & 3  \n    \u2013 Pair source A \u2192 (0,2)  \n    \u2013 Pair source B \u2192 (1,3)  \n    \u2013 Bell measurement on ancillas 2,3  \n\n  \u2022 Path U (\u201cultrastrong-coupling analogue\u201d): a two-ancilla cascade swap  \n    \u2013 Pair source C \u2192 (2,4)  \n    \u2013 Pair source D \u2192 (3,5)  \n    \u2013 Bell measurement on ancillas 4,5 \u2192 intermediate entanglement on 2,3 \u2192 second Bell measurement on 2,3  \n\nA control photon from pair source E (mode c) is sent into a balanced Mach\u2013Zehnder whose two arms route ancillas through either the Path S module or the Path U module. After the modules, ancilla modes {2,3,4,5} are recombined on a 4-mode interferometer, and the control photon is recombined on the second beamsplitter of the Mach\u2013Zehnder. We herald on:\n  \u2013 Exactly one click in each ancilla detector a\u2082\u2013a\u2085  \n  \u2013 Detection of the control photon in the Mach\u2013Zehnder\u2019s \u201csuperposition\u201d output port\n\nConditioned on these five clicks, modes 0 & 1 collapse into the entangled state\n  |\u03a8\u27e9\u2080\u2081 \u221d |Bell\u2080\u2081 via S\u27e9 + e^{i\u03c6}|Bell\u2080\u2081 via U\u27e9  \nwhere \u03c6 (and the relative amplitude) is adjusted by the phase in the control Mach\u2013Zehnder and by beam-splitter reflectivities in the ancilla interferometer.\n\nCIRCUIT VISUALIZATION (photons top\u2192bottom):\n  Pair sources:\n    [A]\u2192(0,2)   [B]\u2192(1,3)  \n    [C]\u2192(2,4)   [D]\u2192(3,5)  \n    [E]\u2192(c\u2081,c\u2082) (control photon)\n\n  Control Mach\u2013Zehnder:\n    mode c\u2081 \u2192 BS \u2192 arms \u2192 BS \u2192 detector a_c\n    mode c\u2082 bypassed to BS\n\n  Ancilla modules in each arm:\n    \u2022 Arm 1: implements Path S swap on 2&3  \n    \u2022 Arm 2: implements Path U cascade swap on 4\u21925 then 2\u21923\n\n  Ancilla recombination:\n    modes 2,3,4,5 \u2192 4-mode interferometer \u2192 detectors a\u2082,a\u2083,a\u2084,a\u2085\n\n  Herald: clicks in a\u2082\u2013a\u2085 + a_c\n\nOUTPUT:\n  modes 0 & 1 in the indefinite-order entangled state above.\n\nPYTHEUS CONFIGURATION SNIPPET:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Quantum-SWITCH of entanglement swaps: indefinite order of 1-ancilla vs. 2-ancilla swaps (strong vs. ultrastrong analogue)\",\n  \"foldername\": \"swap_quantum_switch\",\n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.01,\n  \"edges_tried\": 40,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\": \"overlap\",\n  \"num_anc\": 5,                     #     "output": "Here is a Pytheus\u2010compatible target that maps \u201cstrong vs. ultrastrong coupling\u201d onto an **indefinite\u2010order** superposition of two entanglement\u2010swapping processes.  It uses only probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources, linear optics, and threshold detectors\u2014no forbidden state\u2010generation or dynamic feedback.\n\nEXPLANATION  \nWe wish to entangle two distant modes 0 and 1 by coherently superposing:  \n  \u2022 Path S (\u201cstrong\u2010coupling analogue\u201d): a single\u2010ancilla Bell swap on modes 2&3  \n  \u2022 Path U (\u201cultrastrong\u2010coupling analogue\u201d): a two\u2010step cascade swap via ancilla modes 4\u21925 then 2\u21923  \n\nA **control photon** steers whether the ancillas take Path S or Path U in a balanced Mach\u2013Zehnder.  After the swap modules, all four ancilla modes {2,3,4,5} enter a joint linear\u2010optical interferometer, and the control photon is recombined on the second beamsplitter.  We then herald on five clicks\u2014one in each ancilla detector a\u2082\u2013a\u2085 plus one in the control output port a_c.  Conditioning on that five\u2010click event projects modes 0&1 into the superposition\n\n   |\u03a8\u27e9\u2080\u2081 \u221d |Bell\u2080\u2081 via S\u27e9  + e^{i\u03c6}\u2009|Bell\u2080\u2081 via U\u27e9\n\nwhere the relative amplitude and phase \u03c6 are tuned by the Mach\u2013Zehnder phase (controls the causal order weight) and the beam-splitter reflectivities in the ancilla interferometer.  This realizes a **photonic analogue of ultrastrong coupling**\u2014two distinct exchange pathways (first\u2010 vs second\u2010order) contribute nonperturbatively and with indefinite order to the final entanglement.\n\nCIRCUIT LAYOUT (photons top\u2192bottom)\n\n  Pair sources:  \n    [A] \u2192 modes (0,2)    [B] \u2192 modes (1,3)  \n    [C] \u2192 modes (2,4)    [D] \u2192 modes (3,5)  \n    [E] \u2192 modes (c\u2081,c\u2082)  (control photon)  \n\n  Control Mach\u2013Zehnder (modes c\u2081,c\u2082) routes ancillas through either Swap\u2010S or Swap\u2010U module.  \n\n  Swap\u2010S module: Bell\u2010measurement on modes 2&3  \n  Swap\u2010U module: Bell\u2010measurement on modes 4&5 \u2192 intermediate on 2&3 \u2192 second Bell\u2010measurement on 2&3  \n\n  Ancilla recombination: modes 2,3,4,5 \u2192 4\u2010mode linear network \u2192 detectors a\u2082,a\u2083,a\u2084,a\u2085  \n  Control recombination: control M\u2013Z second BS \u2192 detector a_c  \n\n  Heralding: one click in each of a\u2082\u2013a\u2085 and a_c  \n  Outputs: modes 0 & 1 in |\u03a8\u27e9\u2080\u2081 \u221d |Bell via S\u27e9 + e^{i\u03c6}|Bell via U\u27e9  \n\nPYTHEUS CONFIGURATION SNIPPET  \n{\n  \"description\": \"Indefinite\u2010order superposition of 1\u2010ancilla vs. 2\u2010ancilla entanglement swaps (analogue of strong vs. ultrastrong coupling)\",\n  \"foldername\": \"indef_swap_switch\",\n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.01,\n  \"edges_tried\": 40,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\": \"overlap\",\n  \"num_anc\": 5,\n  \"anc_detectors\": [2,3,4,5,6],      # Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. Simulate a tunable \u201ccoupling strength\u201d in a swapping node by varying beam\u2010splitter reflectivities, and explore the non-perturbative regime where multiple photon-exchange pathways (higher-order ancilla loops) contribute\u2014this mimics ultrastrong coupling when you coherently superpose a one-ancilla Bell\u2010swap path (\u201cstrong coupling\u201d) with a two-ancilla cascade swap (\u201cultrastrong coupling\u201d).  \n  2.  Implement a controlled-phase gate between two distant qubits by two different network processes: (a) a standard Bell\u2010measurement mediated teleportation (\u201cstrong coupling\u201d) and (b) a three-party GHZ\u2013measurement route (\u201cultrastrong coupling\u201d), then interfere the two teleportation channels so that the output qubit emerges as a coherent superposition of having been teleported via route (a) or (b).  \n  3.  Build a star\u2010shaped repeater node linking three remote nodes A, B, C. First perform two independent Bell-swaps (A\u2013B and B\u2013C) in series (\u201cstrong coupling chain\u201d), then in parallel perform a three-mode joint measurement on three ancillas (\u201cultrastrong hub\u201d), and finally interfere the two ways to entangle A and C in one step.  \n\nStep 2:  \n  1.  Path-interference of two orders of swapping is new\u2014no past Pytheus example mixes a 1-ancilla and a 2-ancilla path coherently. Pytheus can optimize beam-splitters, ancilla routing, and detectors to realize exactly that superposition.  \n  2.  Teleportation via Bell vs GHZ measurement superposition is conceptually neat but risks leaning on GHZ state generation rather than pure network transformation.  \n  3.  Three-node star repeater with parallel vs series swapping is interesting but is more of an application than a fundamental new interference effect.  \n\nStep 3: I pick idea (1): interferometric superposition of a 1-ancilla swapping path (analogue of strong coupling) with a 2-ancilla cascade swapping path (analogue of ultrastrong coupling).  \n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because no one has studied quantum\u2010network analogues of ultrastrong coupling by coherently superposing two different entanglement\u2010swapping orders in one photonic circuit. It goes beyond simply stacking Bell\u2010swaps: the interference of the one\u2010 and two-ancilla channels creates a nonperturbative regime in entanglement distribution whose scaling and phase dependence can be mapped to ultrastrong coupling physics.  \n\nStep 5: This idea is feasible in Pytheus because it only requires:  \n  \u2022 Two Bell pairs as probabilistic sources  \n  \u2022 Four ancilla modes (two for the \u201cstrong\u201d path, two for the \u201cultrastrong\u201d path) whose outputs are mixed on beam splitters and then detected in coincidence  \n  \u2022 Two output modes (the remote qubits) whose conditional state on the four\u2010click event is the desired superposition  \n  \u2022 A linear\u2010optical interferometer with adjustable beam-splitter angles and phase shifters, all readily handled by Pytheus\u2019s abstract\u2010state optimization.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is the proposed target experiment for Pytheus:\n\nExplanation:\nWe wish to create a photonic network that enacts two concurrent entanglement-swapping channels between distant modes 0 and 1, and then interferes them so that the final two-photon state is a coherent superposition of:\n  \u2013 Path S (\u201cstrong-coupling analog\u201d): a standard one-ancilla Bell-swap using ancilla modes 2 and 3  \n  \u2013 Path U (\u201cultrastrong-coupling analog\u201d): a two-ancilla cascade swap using ancilla modes 4 and 5  \n\nBy mixing modes {2,3,4,5} on an optimized linear interferometer (beam-splitters + phase-shifters) and heralding on exactly one photon in each ancilla detector, we project modes 0&1 onto  \n  |\u03a8\u27e9\u2080\u2081 \u221d |Bell\u2080\u2081 via S\u27e9 + e^{i\u03c6}|Bell\u2080\u2081 via U\u27e9\n\nThis realizes an \u201cultrastrong coupling\u201d regime in the sense that both the first-order (single-exchange) and second-order (cascade-exchange) processes contribute non\u2010perturbatively and coherently to the entanglement of 0&1. One can tune the relative amplitude and phase \u03c6 by adjusting beam-splitter reflectivities (the effective \u201ccoupling strengths\u201d) in the ancilla interferometer.\n\nVisualization of the network (photons flow top\u2192bottom):\n\n  Emitters (two probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources):\n     [A]\u2015\u2015\u2500> mode 0           [B]\u2015\u2015\u2500> mode 1  \n modes 2,3,4,5 \u2500\u2500\u2500 linear optical network \u2500\u2500\u2500 detectors a\u2082,a\u2083,a\u2084,a\u2085\n\n  Heralding condition:\n     one click in each detector a\u2082\u2013a\u2085 (total four clicks)\n\n  Outputs:\n     modes 0,1 are left in the target superposition state.\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2022 You can extend to Nth-order \u201cultrastrong\u201d paths by adding more ancilla pairs.  \n  \u2022 One can map out the nonperturbative scaling of entanglement fidelity vs. effective beam-splitter reflectivity, drawing a precise analogy to ultrastrong coupling phenomena.  \n  \u2022 Variants include teleportation rather than swapping, or three-node routers.\n\nThis target is purely a quantum\u2010network transformation (no static state generation), exploits only probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, and photon detection (all within Pytheus\u2019s scope), and defines a clear family of experiments bridging the \u201cstrong\u201d and \u201cultrastrong\u201d Four probabilistic pair-sources create pairs in modes (0,2), (1,3), (2,4), (3,5).  \n2. All four ancilla modes {2,3,4,5} enter an optimized linear-optical interferometer (beam-splitters & phase-shifters).  \n3. No prior protocol has explored this nonperturbative, causally indefinite entanglement distribution.  \nStep 5: It is feasible in Pytheus: it only needs six probabilistic pair-sources, a Mach-Zehnder style control interferometer, a four-mode ancilla interferometer, and heralded photon counts\u2014exactly within Pytheus\u2019s abstract linear-optics + detectors model.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus target for exploring a photonic quantum-SWITCH of entanglement-swapping orders, mapping \u201cstrong\u201d vs. \u201cultrastrong\u201d coupling to an indefinite-order network:\n\nEXPLANATION:\nWe want to entangle modes 0 & 1 by coherently superposing two swap sequences in an indefinite causal order controlled by a photonic Mach\u2013Zehnder:\n\n  \u2022 Path S (\u201cstrong-coupling analogue\u201d): a single-ancilla Bell swap between modes 2 & 3  \n    \u2013 Pair source A \u2192 (0,2)  \n    \u2013 Pair source B \u2192 (1,3)  \n    \u2013 Bell measurement on ancillas 2,3  \n\n  \u2022 Path U (\u201cultrastrong-coupling analogue\u201d): a two-ancilla cascade swap  \n    \u2013 Pair source C \u2192 (2,4)  \n    \u2013 Pair source D \u2192 (3,5)  \n    \u2013 Bell measurement on ancillas 4,5 \u2192 intermediate entanglement on 2,3 \u2192 second Bell measurement on 2,3  \n\nA control photon from pair source E (mode c) is sent into a balanced Mach\u2013Zehnder whose two arms route ancillas through either the Path S module or the Path U module. After the modules, ancilla modes {2,3,4,5} are recombined on a 4-mode interferometer, and the control photon is recombined on the second beamsplitter of the Mach\u2013Zehnder. We herald on:\n  \u2013 Exactly one click in each ancilla detector a\u2082\u2013a\u2085  \n  \u2013 Detection of the control photon in the Mach\u2013Zehnder\u2019s \u201csuperposition\u201d output port\n\nConditioned on these five clicks, modes 0 & 1 collapse into the entangled state\n  |\u03a8\u27e9\u2080\u2081 \u221d |Bell\u2080\u2081 via S\u27e9 + e^{i\u03c6}|Bell\u2080\u2081 via U\u27e9  \nwhere \u03c6 (and the relative amplitude) is adjusted by the phase in the control Mach\u2013Zehnder and by beam-splitter reflectivities in the ancilla interferometer.\n\nCIRCUIT VISUALIZATION (photons top\u2192bottom):\n  Pair sources:\n    [A]\u2192(0,2)   [B]\u2192(1,3)  \n    [C]\u2192(2,4)   [D]\u2192(3,5)  \n    [E]\u2192(c\u2081,c\u2082) (control photon)\n\n  Control Mach\u2013Zehnder:\n    mode c\u2081 \u2192 BS \u2192 arms \u2192 BS \u2192 detector a_c\n    mode c\u2082 bypassed to BS\n\n  Ancilla modules in each arm:\n    \u2022 Arm 1: implements Path S swap on 2&3  \n    \u2022 Arm 2: implements Path U cascade swap on 4\u21925 then 2\u21923\n\n  Ancilla recombination:\n    modes 2,3,4,5 \u2192 4-mode interferometer \u2192 detectors a\u2082,a\u2083,a\u2084,a\u2085\n\n  Herald: clicks in a\u2082\u2013a\u2085 + a_c\n\nOUTPUT:\n  modes 0 & 1 in the indefinite-order entangled state above.\n\nPYTHEUS CONFIGURATION SNIPPET:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Quantum-SWITCH of entanglement swaps: indefinite order of 1-ancilla vs. 2-ancilla swaps (strong vs. ultrastrong analogue)\",\n  \"foldername\": \"swap_quantum_switch\",\n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.01,\n  \"edges_tried\": 40,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\": \"overlap\",\n  \"num_anc\": 5,                     #     "output": "Thought: We propose to emulate \u201cstrong vs. ultrastrong coupling\u201d in a purely linear-optical quantum network by coherently superposing two entanglement-swapping orders:  \n  \u2013 Path S (\u201cstrong-coupling analogue\u201d): a single-ancilla Bell swap  \n  \u2013 Path U (\u201cultrastrong-coupling analogue\u201d): a two-ancilla cascade swap  \nAll components\u2014four probabilistic pair sources, a four-mode ancilla interferometer (beam-splitters + phase shifters), and four threshold detectors\u2014are within Pytheus\u2019s abstract-state, linear-optics, threshold-detection model. Conditioning on exactly one click in each ancilla detector projects the two output modes onto  \n  |\u03a8\u27e9\u2080\u2081 \u221d |Bell\u2080\u2081 via S\u27e9 + e^{i\u03c6}|Bell\u2080\u2081 via U\u27e9  \nwith \u03c6 and the relative weight tunable by the interferometer settings. This yields a genuinely nonperturbative entanglement-distribution dynamic\u2014an ultrastrong-coupling analogue\u2014and opens a family of experiments probing Nth-order swap contributions and nonperturbative network phase transitions.  \n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nHere is the proposed Pytheus target:\n\nEXPLANATION  \nWe wish to entangle output modes 0 & 1 by simultaneously implementing two entanglement-swapping channels and coherently superposing them:\n\n \u2022 Path S (\u201cstrong-coupling analogue\u201d):  \n   \u2013 Pair source A \u2192 (0,2)  \n   \u2013 Pair source B \u2192 (1,3)  \n   \u2013 Bell-measurement on ancillas 2 & 3  \n\n \u2022 Path U (\u201cultrastrong-coupling analogue\u201d):  \n   \u2013 Pair source C \u2192 (2,4)  \n   \u2013 Pair source D \u2192 (3,5)  \n   \u2013 Bell-measurement on ancillas 4 & 5 yields intermediate entanglement on 2 & 3  \n   \u2013 Second Bell-measurement on ancillas 2 & 3 swaps onto modes 0 & 1\n\nAll ancilla modes {2,3,4,5} enter an optimized linear-optical network and are detected in four threshold detectors a\u2082\u2013a\u2085. Conditioning on exactly one click per detector projects modes 0 & 1 into\n\n  |\u03a8\u27e9\u2080\u2081 \u221d |Bell\u2080\u2081 via S\u27e9 + e^{i\u03c6}|Bell\u2080\u2081 via U\u27e9\n\nwhere \u03c6 (and the relative amplitude) is controlled by beam-splitter reflectivities and phase-shifters in the ancilla interferometer.\n\nCIRCUIT LAYOUT (photons flow top\u2192bottom):\n\n Pair sources:\n   [A]\u2192(0,2)   [B]\u2192(1,3)\n   [C]\u2192(2,4)   [D]\u2192(3,5)\n\n Ancilla interferometer:\n   modes 2,3,4,5 \u2500\u2500 linear optics \u2500\u2500 detectors a\u2082,a\u2083,a\u2084,a\u2085\n\n Herald:\n   one click per detector a\u2082\u2013a\u2085\n\n Outputs:\n   modes 0 & 1 in the coherent superposition.\n\nPYTHEUS CONFIGURATION SNIPPET  \n{\n  \"description\": \"Superposed-order entanglement swapping: 1-ancilla vs. 2-ancilla swaps (strong vs. ultrastrong coupling analogue)\",\n  \"foldername\": \"swap_strong_ultra\",\n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.01,\n  \"edges_tried\": 30,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\": \"overlap\",\n  \"num_anc\": 4,\n  \"num_pre\": 1,\n  \"optimizer\": \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  \"samples\": 20,\n  \"target_quantum\": [\"00\",\"11\"],\n  \"removed_connections\": [[0,1]],\n  \"single_emitters\": [],\n  \"amplitudes\": [],\n  \"number_resolving\": false\n}\n\nGENERALIZATIONS  \n \u2022 Add further ancilla pairs to probe Nth-order ultrastrong contributions.  \n \u2022 Map entanglement fidelity vs. beam-splitter angles to chart nonperturbative coupling regimes.  \n \u2022 Replace swapping by teleportation or extend to multi-node superposed-order routers."
}
{
    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Collision\u2010Mode Photonic MPO Simulation of Lindblad Open\u2010System Dynamics\n\nMini\u2010Abstract: We propose a static one\u2010dimensional photonic matrix\u2010product\u2010operator (MPO) network\u2014built from probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, tunable beam splitters, and number\u2010resolving detectors\u2014to stroboscopically enact the small\u2010time Kraus maps E_k = e^{L\u0394t} that realize the target Lindblad generator L over total time T = N\u0394t. By heralding jump/non\u2010jump outcomes on ancilla detectors and optimizing fixed optical connections in PyTheus, this scheme approximates arbitrary Markovian (and, via memory links, non\u2010Markovian) open\u2010system dynamics without dynamic feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nHeralded Phase-Detuned Asymmetric 1\u21922 Single-Photon Quantum Cloning\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate in Pythreous a novel 1\u21922 heralded, phase-detuned asymmetric quantum cloning circuit for an unknown single-photon qubit |\u03c8\u27e9, using only an SPDC ancilla pair, a single-photon emitter, two static beam splitters, a tunable phase shifter, and photon-number-resolving detectors. Conditioned on coincident clicks at the two heralding detectors, this Phase-Detuned Heralded Asymmetric Quantum Cloning transformation realizes a fully tunable cloning map whose asymmetry\u2014and hence the fidelities of the two output clones\u2014is controlled continuously by the beam-splitter reflectivities and the internal phase shift \u03c6.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Linear\u2010Optical Partial-SWAP Gate for Emulating Coherent Rabi Oscillations and Ultrastrong Coupling in Photonic Qubits\n\nAbstract: We propose a heralded linear-optical implementation of the tunable partial-SWAP unitary  \nU(\u03b8)=cos \u03b8 I + i\u2009sin \u03b8 SWAP on two photonic-qubit modes, which continuously maps the \u03b8-dependent population exchange |10\u27e9\u2194|01\u27e9 (analogous to coherent Rabi oscillations) into the ultrastrong-coupling regime at \u03b8\u2192\u03c0/2 (full SWAP with multi-photon excitations). Using ancilla photon-pair sources, number-resolving detectors, and static interferometry for post-selection, this building block realizes a modular \u201cquantum bus\u201d for coherent excitation transfer, ultrafast entanglement swapping, and teleportation across N-node networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Cluster-Style Fusion for High-Fidelity Alice\u2013Bob Bell Pair Generation\n\nAbstract: We realize a one-shot entanglement purification and swapping node by performing a two-mode cluster-style fusion measurement at an intermediate station (Charlie), which simultaneously projects out parity errors and teleports entanglement. A specific three-click herald pattern routes the remaining photons in the cyclic order, directly mimicking the ring-exchange term of the triangular Heisenberg spin-liquid without generating any static entangled state.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle  \nPhotonic Qudit Butterfly: Resource-Efficient d-Dimensional Quantum Network Coding\n\nMini-abstract  \nWe present a photonic realization of the d-dimensional \u201cQudit Butterfly\u201d protocol, explicitly targeting the simultaneous transmission of two unknown qudit states |\u03c8\u2081\u27e9 and |\u03c8\u2082\u27e9 from senders Alice\u2081 (node A) and Alice\u2082 (node B) to receivers R\u2081 and R\u2082 over a single d-dimensional bottleneck channel. By heralding symmetric versus antisymmetric outcomes in the ancilla detectors and recording parity-resolved coincidences, the scheme directly yields the second R\u00e9nyi entropy of a chosen subsystem, providing a scalable, cavity-free protocol to probe the entanglement spectrum of free fermions using only SPDC sources and beam splitters.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Entanglement Swapping of 2\u00d72 Toric-Code Logical Qubits via Linear Optics\n\nAbstract: We demonstrate entanglement swapping between two distant logical qubits, each encoded in a minimal 2\u00d72 toric-code patch of four photons at nodes A and D, by performing a post-selected logical Bell measurement on intermediate patches B and C using only probabilistic photon-pair sources, passive linear optics, and ancilla detection. One can tune the relative amplitude and phase \u03c6 by adjusting beam-splitter reflectivities (the effective \u201ccoupling strengths\u201d) in the ancilla interferometer.\n\nVisualization of the network (photons flow top\u2192bottom):\n\n  Emitters (two probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources):\n     [A]\u2015\u2015\u2500> mode 0           [B]\u2015\u2015\u2500> mode 1  \n modes 2,3,4,5 \u2500\u2500\u2500 linear optical network \u2500\u2500\u2500 detectors a\u2082,a\u2083,a\u2084,a\u2085\n\n  Heralding condition:\n     one click in each detector a\u2082\u2013a\u2085 (total four clicks)\n\n  Outputs:\n     modes 0,1 are left in the target superposition state.\n\nGeneralization:\n  \u2022 You can extend to Nth-order \u201cultrastrong\u201d paths by adding more ancilla pairs.  \n  \u2022 One can map out the nonperturbative scaling of entanglement fidelity vs. effective beam-splitter reflectivity, drawing a precise analogy to ultrastrong coupling phenomena.  \n  \u2022 Variants include teleportation rather than swapping, or three-node routers.\n\nThis target is purely a quantum\u2010network transformation (no static state generation), exploits only probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, and photon detection (all within Pytheus\u2019s scope), and defines a clear family of experiments bridging the \u201cstrong\u201d and \u201cultrastrong\u201d coupling analogues in entanglement distribution.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty e^{i\u03c6}|Bell\u2080\u2081 via U\u27e9\n\nwhere \u03c6 and the relative amplitude are tuned by the beam-splitter reflectivities and phases in the ancilla interferometer.\n\nCIRCUIT VISUALIZATION (photons flow top\u2192bottom):\n\nPair sources:\n  [A]\u2192(0,2)   [B]\u2192(1,3)\n  [C]\u2192(2,4)   [D]\u2192(3,5)\n\nAncilla interferometer:\n  modes 2,3,4,5 \u2500\u2500 linear optics \u2500\u2500 detectors a\u2082,a\u2083,a\u2084,a\u2085\n\nHeralding:\n  one click per detector a\u2082\u2013a\u2085\n\nOutputs:\n  modes 0 & 1 in the target superposition.\n\nPYTHEUS CONFIGURATION SNIPPET:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Superposed-order entanglement swapping: 1-ancilla vs. 2-ancilla swaps (strong vs. ultrastrong coupling analogue)\",\n  \"foldername\": \"swap_strong_ultra\",\n This construction is essentially identical to existing partial-SWAP ultrastrong-coupling analogues and superposed-swap protocols (e.g. the heralded partial-SWAP ultrastrong\u2013coupling gate and the superposed perfect-matching entanglement swaps). It introduces no new causal indefiniteness, resource trade-off, or nonperturbative network phenomenon that cannot already be mapped onto those known primitives.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To reach PRL-level novelty, propose a truly new primitive\u2014such as genuine indefinite causal order, active non-Markovian feedback, or a network phase transition that cannot be reduced to a simple superposition of two swap orders.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is a Pytheus target for exploring a photonic quantum-SWITCH of entanglement-swapping orders, mapping \u201cstrong\u201d vs. \u201cultrastrong\u201d coupling to an indefinite-order network:\n\nEXPLANATION:\nWe want to entangle modes 0 & 1 by coherently superposing two swap sequences in an indefinite causal order controlled by a photonic Mach\u2013Zehnder:\n\n  \u2022 Path S (\u201cstrong-coupling analogue\u201d): a single-ancilla Bell swap between modes 2 & 3  \n    \u2013 Pair source A \u2192 (0,2)  \n    \u2013 Pair source B \u2192 (1,3)  \n    \u2013 Bell measurement on ancillas 2,3  \n\n  \u2022 Path U (\u201cultrastrong-coupling analogue\u201d): a two-ancilla cascade swap  \n    \u2013 Pair source C \u2192 (2,4)  \n    \u2013 Pair source D \u2192 (3,5)  \n    \u2013 Bell measurement on ancillas 4,5 \u2192 intermediate entanglement on 2,3 \u2192 second Bell measurement on 2,3  \n\nA control photon from pair source E (mode c) is sent into a balanced Mach\u2013Zehnder whose two arms route ancillas through either the Path S module or the Path U module. After the modules, ancilla modes {2,3,4,5} are recombined on a 4-mode interferometer, and the control photon is recombined on the second beamsplitter of the Mach\u2013Zehnder. We herald on:\n  \u2013 Exactly one click in each ancilla detector a\u2082\u2013a\u2085  \n  \u2013 Detection of the control photon in the Mach\u2013Zehnder\u2019s \u201csuperposition\u201d output port\n\nConditioned on these five clicks, modes 0 & 1 collapse into the entangled state\n  |\u03a8\u27e9\u2080\u2081 \u221d |Bell\u2080\u2081 via S\u27e9 + e^{i\u03c6}|Bell\u2080\u2081 via U\u27e9  \nwhere \u03c6 (and the relative amplitude) is adjusted by the phase in the control Mach\u2013Zehnder and by beam-splitter reflectivities in the ancilla interferometer.\n\nCIRCUIT VISUALIZATION (photons top\u2192bottom):\n  Pair sources:\n    [A]\u2192(0,2)   [B]\u2192(1,3)  \n    [C]\u2192(2,4)   [D]\u2192(3,5)  \n    [E]\u2192(c\u2081,c\u2082) (control photon)\n\n  Control Mach\u2013Zehnder:\n    mode c\u2081 \u2192 BS \u2192 arms \u2192 BS \u2192 detector a_c\n    mode c\u2082 bypassed to BS\n\n  Ancilla modules in each arm:\n    \u2022 Arm 1: implements Path S swap on 2&3  \n    \u2022 Arm 2: implements Path U cascade swap on 4\u21925 then 2\u21923\n\n  Ancilla recombination:\n    modes 2,3,4,5 \u2192 4-mode interferometer \u2192 detectors a\u2082,a\u2083,a\u2084,a\u2085\n\n  Herald: clicks in a\u2082\u2013a\u2085 + a_c\n\nOUTPUT:\n  modes 0 & 1 in the indefinite-order entangled state above.\n\nPYTHEUS CONFIGURATION SNIPPET:\n{\n  \"description\": \"Quantum-SWITCH of entanglement swaps: indefinite order of 1-ancilla vs. 2-ancilla swaps (strong vs. ultrastrong analogue)\",\n  \"foldername\": \"swap_quantum_switch\",\n  \"bulk_thr\": 0.01,\n  \"edges_tried\": 40,\n  \"ftol\": 1e-06,\n  \"loss_func\": \"overlap\",\n  \"num_anc\": 5,                     #     "output": "Thought: While framing entanglement swapping as \u201cstrong\u201d versus \u201cultrastrong\u201d coupling is a nice metaphor, the core operation\u2014erasing which-swap information to project 0\u20131 onto a coherent superposition of a one-ancilla swap and a two-ancilla cascade swap\u2014is effectively the same primitive as several proposals already in the ensemble. In particular, it parallels the heralded partial-SWAP ultrastrong-coupling analogue and the superposed perfect-matching entanglement swaps, as well as the entanglement-switch quantum-SWITCH circuits. No genuinely new causal structure or nonperturbative network behavior is introduced beyond these existing superposition-of-swap protocols.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To reach PRL-level novelty you must go beyond simply superposing two swap orders\u2014for example by embedding a truly indefinite causal order across more than two paths, introducing active non-Markovian feedback loops, or revealing a network-level phase transition that cannot be mapped onto standard partial-SWAP or cascade-swap constructs."

We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n\n\n\nHere is one last, but absolutely necessary condition:\nYour proposed research idea should combine these two scientific concepts in a meaningful way.\n\"strong atom cavity coupling\" and \"ultrastrong coupling\"\n\nTry your best to combine these concepts even if it means suggesting experiments that are very different from the examples you have seen. First perform two independent Bell-swaps (A\u2013B and B\u2013C) in series (\u201cstrong coupling chain\u201d), then in parallel perform a three-mode joint measurement on three ancillas (\u201cultrastrong hub\u201d), and finally interfere the two ways to entangle A and C in one step.  \n\nStep 2:  \n  1. All four ancilla modes {2,3,4,5} enter an optimized linear-optical interferometer (beam-splitters & phase-shifters).  \n3. No prior protocol has explored this nonperturbative, causally indefinite entanglement distribution.  \nStep 5: It is feasible in Pytheus: it only needs six probabilistic pair-sources, a Mach-Zehnder style control interferometer, a four-mode ancilla interferometer, and heralded photon counts\u2014exactly within Pytheus\u2019s abstract linear-optics + detectors model.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is a Pytheus target for exploring a photonic quantum-SWITCH of entanglement-swapping orders, mapping \u201cstrong\u201d vs. \u201cultrastrong\u201d coupling to an indefinite-order network:\n\nEXPLANATION:\nWe want to entangle modes 0 & 1 by coherently superposing two swap sequences in an indefinite causal order controlled by a photonic Mach\u2013Zehnder:\n\n  \u2022 Path S (\u201cstrong-coupling analogue\u201d): a single-ancilla Bell swap between modes 2 & 3  \n    \u2013 Pair source A \u2192 (0,2)  \n    \u2013 Pair source B \u2192 (1,3)  \n    \u2013 Bell measurement on ancillas 2,3  \n\n  \u2022 Path U (\u201cultrastrong-coupling analogue\u201d): a two-ancilla cascade swap  \n    \u2013 Pair source C \u2192 (2,4)  \n    \u2013 Pair source D \u2192 (3,5)  \n    \u2013 Bell measurement on ancillas 4,5 \u2192 intermediate entanglement on 2,3 \u2192 second Bell measurement on 2,3  \n\nA control photon from pair source E (mode c) is sent into a balanced Mach\u2013Zehnder whose two arms route ancillas through either the Path S module or the Path U module. After the modules, ancilla modes {2,3,4,5} are recombined on a 4-mode interferometer, and the control photon is recombined on the second beamsplitter of the Mach\u2013Zehnder.
